sentence: A builder of ever-brighter and long-lived LED lights that use little energy, Cree describes itself as leading the LED lighting revolution.
Just last week it debuted what it calls the industry's brightest LED (light-emitting diode) module with high color quality, the 6,000-lumen LMH2 LED.

While LEDs have made inroads as an energy-efficient lighting option, making them bright enough to compete with all traditional lighting options -- with ideal color quality -- has proved to be a challenge.

Offering 85 lumens of light per watt across a wide color-temperature range, Cree's new module can be used in place of 100-watt lamps in high-ceiling locations such as malls, convention centers and airports.
It uses 30% less power than ceramic-metal-halide lamps used in such spots and can be dimmed.
What sets the Durham, N.C., company's products apart?
The unique technology thatCree ( CREE ) uses to manufacture the modules delivers more light per watt, resulting in greater efficiencies.
"Cree has a reputation for producing the best, high-flex chips for the lighting market," said Craig Irwin, an analyst at Wedbush Securities.
"What makes them unique versus their peers is their manufacturing approach using silicon carbide.
Everybody else is using sapphire."
In addition to making better-performing chips, Cree has a nearly exclusive focus on the lighting market, making it an attractive pure-play investment in the U.S.
LED space.
Cree started out as an LED component supplier, but has evolved into a vertically integrated company selling not only components, but also packaged products and lighting fixtures.
It makes its own LED products for individual sale, and technology that goes into its lighting fixtures, plus it sells its LED components to other companies in the lighting fixtures space.

"Back in 2006 and 2007, we made the bet to try to make the market and push it to 100% adoption of LED lighting technology at a time when everyone thought it was impossible and no one was moving in that direction," said Mike Watson, vice president of product strategy at Cree.
In March 2013, Cree introduced its first LED bulb for the consumer market.
Via an exclusive distributorship withHome Depot ( HD ), Cree's LED bulbs have become "the number one selling lighting SKU at Home Depot," said Watson.
Watson notes that $1 trillion of installed light systems exist worldwide.
Roughly 80% of that is commercial and industrial, with the remainder consumer and residential.
While the commercial market will always be the most important revenue driver for Cree, the consumer market finds its importance in being the adoption driver.
"As we're seeing the adoption curve really start to take off now, this is when you can see some really lucrative opportunities in this industry," said Morningstar analyst Carr Lanphier.
Cree has been pretty aggressive with pricing, despite offering a superior product, to stimulate consumer adoption and feed customer loyalty in the longer term, Lanphier says.
Currently, LED lighting accounts for 15% to 20% of the global lighting market.

A recent study by Lux Research forecasts that "driven by superior features and falling costs, the market for light-emitting diode (LED) luminaires, or optimized permanent light fixtures, will grow more than 12-fold over the next decade -- from $2 billion today to $25 billion in 2023, a compound annual growth rate ( CAGR ) of 25%."

With a new phase of a ban on many U.S. incandescent light bulbs in effect at the start of this year, part of an energy-efficiency push, Lanphier believes that there is ample room for Cree's domestic growth.
Under this phase of the ban, 40- and 60-watt incandescent bulbs cannot be manufactured anymore, but can still be sold until stores run out, and consumers are allowed to have and buy them.
The 100-watt incandescent bulbs were phased out in 2012 and the 75-watt bulbs last year, though some kinds and more energy-efficient wattages of incandescents are exempt from the ban.
More and more countries are enacting similar bans, which should enhance LED makers' positions.

"The (incandescent) bulbs are incredibly energy-inefficient and the majority of Western countries right now have energy grids that are overtaxed and by increasing the energy efficiency of light bulbs, you can reduce the strain on the energy grid," Lanphier said.
Many governments and utility companies are providing subsidies and rebates for going LED.
A notable example of the adoption of energy-efficient LED lighting is in Los Angeles street lights.
In 2013, the city of Los Angeles decided to upgrade more than 140,000 streetlights.
As a result, Cree became the leading supplier to the largest LED streetlight replacement program in the world.
The efficiency of Cree's technology translates into profitable products and impressive gross margins, despite a lot of pricing pressures in the market.

Cree's gross margin in LED components stood at 39% in 2012, jumped to 45% in 2013 and is forecast at 46% this year, according to Edwin Mok, an analyst at Needham & Co.

"Relative to that, some of the Asian competitors that make LED components that compete with Cree had negative gross margins," said Mok.
This indicates that Cree's technology is highly valued, he noted.
Nevertheless, Mok believes that margins will be mostly range-bound going forward.
Analysts also say much growth is likely already factored into the stock price.

Another risk is if a large lighting and consumer electronics company such asPhilips ( PHG ) orGeneral Electric ( GE ) -- that currently are competitors selling LED products -- decides to expand its market presence and "start throwing a very large R&D budget behind some of the second-tier LED technology guys," noted Lanphier.
On Jan. 21, Cree reported its fiscal second-quarter 2014 results.
Revenue rose 20% to $415.1 million, ahead of the consensus of $412.3 million, while earnings per share surged 44% to 46 cents, ahead of the 39-cent expectation of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.
Cree focuses on innovating and providing value.
"It's not about staying ahead of the competition; it's about staying ahead of and meeting the consumer needs," said Watson.

"As long as we're doing that most affordably and providing the greatest value, I think we're going to be OK."

This week, Cree came out with a self-programming wireless lighting control system it calls SmartCast Technology.

Cree says the system, which looks like a small remote control, costs half of a traditional lighting control and saves 70% in energy consumption vs. traditional fluorescent light fixtures without the technology.
With the wireless system, SmartCast-enabled fixtures can create their own secure network and "learn about" their environment.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
